answer_html: More generally, if \(f(x) = p(x)\) and \(g(x) = p(x) + c\) where \(p(x)\) is a differentiable function, then \(f'(x) = p'(x)\) but \(f(x) \not= g(x)\).
answer_latex:
More generally, if $f(x) = p(x)$ and $g(x) = p(x) + c$ where $p(x)$ is a
differentiable function, then $f'(x) = p'(x)$ but
$f(x) \not= g(x)$.
hints_html: Can you think of two functions which are different, but have the same derivative? What parts of a function can disappear after taking the derivative?
hints_latex:
Can you think of two functions which are different, but have the same
derivative? What parts of a function can disappear after taking the
derivative?
hints_raw: Can you think of two functions which are different, but have the same derivative?  What parts of a function can disappear after taking the derivative?
question: 1 (c)
sols_html:
The statement is false. If we have two functions that only differ by a constant, when we take the derivative the constant will disappear, making the derivatives equal. However the original functions were not equal to start with.

A simple concrete example would be: suppose \(f(x) = x^2 + 2\) and \(g(x) = x^2\). Even though their derivatives are equal,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(x) = g'(x) = 2x\end{aligned}\]

the original functions aren’t equal.

More generally, if \(f(x) = p(x)\) and \(g(x) = p(x) + c\) where \(p(x)\) is a differentiable function, then \(f'(x) = g'(x) = p'(x)\) but \(f(x) \not= g(x)\).
sols_latex:
The statement is false. If we have two functions that only differ by a
constant, when we take the derivative the constant will disappear,
making the derivatives equal. However the original functions were not
equal to start with.

A simple concrete example would be: suppose $f(x) = x^2 + 2$ and
$g(x) = x^2$. Even though their derivatives are equal,

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle f'(x) = g'(x) = 2x
\end{align*}

the original functions aren't equal.

More generally, if $f(x) = p(x)$ and $g(x) = p(x) + c$ where $p(x)$ is a
differentiable function, then $f'(x) = g'(x) = p'(x)$ but
$f(x) \not= g(x)$.
sols_raw:
The statement is false.  If we have two functions that only differ by a constant, when we take the derivative the constant will disappear, making the derivatives equal.  However the original functions were not equal to start with.  

A simple concrete example would be: suppose <math>f(x) = x^2 + 2</math> and <math>g(x) = x^2</math>.  Even though their derivatives are equal,

:<math> \displaystyle f'(x) = g'(x) = 2x</math>

the original functions aren't equal.  

More generally, if <math>f(x) = p(x)</math> and <math>g(x) = p(x) + c</math> where <math>p(x)</math> is a differentiable function, then <math>f'(x) = g'(x) = p'(x)</math> but <math>f(x) \not= g(x)</math>.
statement_html:
Determine whether this statement is true. If it is, explain why; if not, give a counter-example.

If \(f'(x) = g'(x)\), then \(f(x) = g(x).\)
statement_raw:
''Determine whether this statement is true. If it is, explain why; if not, give a counter-example.''

If <math>f'(x) = g'(x)</math>, then <math>f(x) = g(x).</math>
